week1.practice1_html:
Toby, your shedding is still in the worsening phase because the illness and recovery stress are ongoing. Right now, less than 5 hours of broken sleep is keeping your cortisol high at night, which delays stabilization. Locking in a steady sleep window is your “big domino”—it lowers those night spikes so your hair can move from shedding onset into stabilization more smoothly 🌙.

What to do

  • Choose a fixed bedtime and aim to be in bed within 30 minutes of it every night, weekend or not.
  • Set a consistent wake-up time anchored to morning light.
  • Give yourself at least an 8-hour sleep opportunity, even if your body only takes 6–7 at first.
  • Place your phone away from the bed to cut doom scrolling before sleep.

Your recommended schedule

  • Bedtime: 11:00–11:30 pm
  • Wake time: 7:00 am daily
  • Keep this window steady for 14 nights to let your circadian rhythm reset.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Pick your wake-up anchor (7:00 am) and set an alarm—even on weekends.
  2. Count back 8 hours to set your bedtime target (by 11 pm). Lights out within 30 min.
  3. Plan last screen use 30 mins before bed so doom scrolling doesn’t push you past your window.
  4. If you wake in the night, avoid checking the clock; return to bed quietly.
  5. Stick with the anchors for 14 days before judging success—your body lags a little behind the new consistency.

Why this works (for you)

  • Your COVID recovery still stresses the body; aligned sleep lowers night cortisol so fewer follicles flip into telogen.
  • Because your peak shedding likely began ~4–8 weeks after illness, steadier circadian rhythms shorten the time from worsening toward stabilization.
  • Regular hormones from consistent sleep support progesterone balance (helpful with your sometimes-PMS and irregular cycles).
  • This protocol makes sure regrowth gets the signal on schedule once illness stressors ease.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: If you still average under 5 hours of total sleep after 2 weeks, note it and consider extra support (from a sleep coach or medical provider).
  • Green lights: Waking at 7 am feels easier by week two; night wakings drop from 3 to 1–2; you notice less clumps on wash days.
  • Be gentle—your body has been through illness. Even small wins (one extra hour of rest) are a step toward calmer scalp days ❤️.
week1.practice2_html:
Toby, your shedding is still in the worsening window—right where fallout from your July over-exercise and September illness would naturally peak. The quickest lever for calming this phase is deeper, steadier sleep. Right now you’re under 5h, with late caffeine and 2–3 awakenings. A wind‑down ritual is the “big domino” that steadies cortisol, shortens the worst-shedding window, and sets you up for the stabilization phase and eventual regrowth ✨.

What to do

  • Set a 30‑min screen‑off buffer (replace doom‑scroll with paper, music, or gentle stretch).
  • Have your last light snack at least 1h before bed to ease digestion.
  • Do a 5‑min slow breathing or guided meditation to quiet rumination.
  • Create a “bridge” ritual (tea, journal, shower) that signals brain → body: time to power down.

Your recommended schedule

  • Wake: 7:00 am fixed every day (anchor circadian rhythm).
  • Wind down: start 10:00 pm.
  • Lights out: 11:00 pm → 7:00 am (target 8‑h window).

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Block calendar alarms at 10:00 pm: “Start wind‑down.”
  2. Put phone in another room; keep one calming task ready (book, journal).
  3. Finish any food by 10:00 pm; sip only water or herbal tea before bed.
  4. Lie down by 11:00 pm; use slow breathing (4s in, 6s out) if racing thoughts start.
  5. Wake at 7:00 am even if sleep was short—consistency builds deeper nights later.

Why this works (for you)

  • Your illness trigger is still ongoing → consistent sleep buffers the cortisol elevation that pushes more follicles into shedding.
  • Anchored wake + ritual speeds the shift from “worsening” to “stabilization,” so you don’t get stuck in a prolonged fallout loop.
  • Replacing doom‑scrolling reduces late‑night blue light + stimulation that fragment deep sleep, the phase tied to repair and growth signals.
  • Longer consistent nights improve hormone rhythm (progesterone, thyroid) that support post‑TE regrowth.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: If you still average <5h nightly after 2 weeks despite routine → consider adding professional sleep support.
  • Green lights: Falling asleep faster (within ~20 min); fewer 2–3 am wake‑ups; slightly less hair left on pillow within 1–2 weeks.
  • Remember ❤️: small shifts every night compound—this is you shortening the storm, not failing when a rough night happens.
week1.practice3_html:
```html

Toby, right now you’re in the onset → peak phase of shedding (illness ongoing, heavy loss >200). Your <5h sleep, late caffeine, and night wakings keep cortisol high at night—exactly when your follicles need repair signals. Creating a caffeine cut‑off is a small lever that stabilizes your sleep curve so shedding can slow and you can move into stabilization on time 🌙.

What to do

  • Enjoy coffee/tea only before 1 pm.
  • Switch to water, herbal tea, or decaf after lunch.
  • Pair your morning caffeine with protein (helps steadier energy, protects hair substrate).
  • Notice afternoons of energy dips—try sunlight or a short walk instead of a cup.

Your recommended schedule

  • Wake anchor: ~7:00 am daily (within 15 min).
  • Target wind‑down start: 10:00 pm.
  • Lights out: 11:00 pm → aim for 7–8 h sleep window.
  • No caffeine past 1:00 pm (hard fence).

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Set a daily alarm titled “Last Caffeine” at 1 pm as your reminder.
  2. Frontload your coffee—have your full serving with breakfast or lunch.
  3. When doom‑scroll urges hit afternoon, swap with a 5‑min sunlight break outside.
  4. Keep herbal tea bags by your workspace for substitution rituals.
  5. Track your sleep: note whether your 2–3 night wakings reduce after a week.

Why this works (for you)

  • Late caffeine fragments sleep → higher night cortisol. Cutting off by 1 pm calms cortisol, which helps slow follicles exiting growth.
  • Your illness trigger (Sept) will likely show peak fallout in Oct–Nov. Better sleep now shortens and flattens this peak, speeding stabilization.
  • Your irregular cycles and low protein meals mean hormones/metabolism are under more pressure; deep sleep supports progesterone + thyroid tone, both linked to hair cycling.

What to look out for

  • Red flags: Still <5h sleep after two weeks → layer in wind‑down stack earlier; if severe, discuss with a professional.
  • Green lights: Fewer night wakings (maybe 1–2 instead of 3). Waking less wired. Slight shedding plateau within 2–3 weeks.
  • You don’t need to be perfect. Every afternoon cup you skip is one win for your follicles ❤️.
```
